responses: Angular is a front-end framework for building Single Page Applications (SPA) using TypeScript and components. It organizes apps with modules, components, services, directives and pipes.
Angular (2+) is a component-based framework written with TypeScript that helps build SPAs with routing, dependency injection, and a rich CLI.

A SPA (Single Page Application) is a web app that loads a single HTML page (index.html) and dynamically updates content using JavaScript—often fetching JSON via HTTP to update the view without full page reloads.

patterns: Do I need TypeScript for Angular?
responses: TypeScript is recommended for Angular because it provides static typing, classes, interfaces, and modern JS features. Angular applications are typically written in TypeScript and transpiled to JavaScript.

HTTP is the protocol for client-server communication. Common methods: GET (read), POST (create/submit), PUT (update/upload), DELETE (remove), HEAD (header info). Status codes like 200, 404, 500 indicate request results.
200 OK means the request succeeded. 201 Created: resource created. 301/302: redirect. 400: bad request. 401: unauthorized. 403: forbidden. 404: not found. 500: server error.
Download Node.js from https://nodejs.org and install it. Node includes npm (Node Package Manager) used to install Angular CLI and other packages.
Install Angular CLI globally with: `npm install -g @angular/cli`. Use `ng` commands to create, build, serve and test Angular projects.

patterns: How to create a new Angular project?
responses: Use `ng new ProjectName` to generate a new Angular project with a scaffolded structure and install dependencies. Then go into the folder and run `ng serve`.

patterns: How to run Angular app locally?
responses: Run `ng serve` from the project root. It compiles TypeScript to JavaScript and starts a dev server at `http://localhost:4200` by default.

patterns: What files are in an Angular project?
responses: Typical structure: `src/index.html` (boot page), `main.ts` (bootstraps AppModule), `app/` (contains components, services, modules), `app.module.ts` (root module).

@NgModule decorates a module class and has metadata: `declarations` (components, directives, pipes), `imports` (other modules), `providers` (services), `bootstrap` (root component). AppModule is the root module bootstrapped by main.ts.

Important @NgModule properties: `declarations` registers components/directives/pipes; `imports` brings other modules; `providers` registers service providers; `bootstrap` names the root component; `exports` exposes components to other modules.

patterns: What is a component in Angular?
responses: A component is a class with an `@Component` decorator that defines a selector, template (or templateUrl) and styleUrls. Use `ng generate component Name` to scaffold a component.

Selectors can be element (`selector: 'app-about'` → ``), attribute (`selector: '[app-about]'` → `
`), or class (`selector: '.app-about'` → `
`).
`template` allows inline HTML in the decorator. `templateUrl` points to an external HTML file. Prefer `templateUrl` for larger templates and `template` for very small inline templates.

patterns: component not part of any NgModule
responses: Components, directives, and pipes must be listed in a module's `declarations` array. If you forget, Angular throws a 'component is not part of any NgModule' error.

patterns: Explain interpolation property binding event binding
responses: Data binding lets you communicate between the component class and template: Interpolation `{{value}}`, Property binding `[src]`, Event binding `(click)`, and Two-way binding `[(ngModel)]`.
To use `[(ngModel)]` import `FormsModule` in your module: `import { FormsModule } from '@angular/forms';` and add `FormsModule` to `imports` in your NgModule.

patterns: How to bind attributes in Angular
responses: Property binding uses square brackets: ``. It sets DOM element properties from component values.

patterns: How to handle clicks in template
responses: Event binding uses parentheses: `<button (click)="doSomething()">Click</button>`. It calls component methods on DOM events.
Two-way binding combines property and event binding: `[(ngModel)]="value"`. It requires `FormsModule` and syncs input and component model.

patterns: How to iterate list in template
responses:
Use `*ngFor="let item of items"` to create repeated elements. Example: `
  • {{c.message}}
    • `.
Use `*ngIf="condition"` to include/exclude elements. You can use `else` with `<ng-template #name>...</ng-template>` for alternatives.

Directives are classes that add behavior to templates. Types: components (with template), structural directives (`*ngIf`, `*ngFor`) that change DOM layout, and attribute directives (e.g. `ngClass`, `ngStyle`) that change element appearance/behavior.

patterns: How to format date in template
responses: Pipes transform displayed values in templates. Example: `{{ dateValue | date:'dd/MM/yyyy' }}`. You can write custom pipes for formatting.
A service is a class (often annotated with `@Injectable`) that provides reusable logic, data access, or utilities. Components consume services via dependency injection (DI).
`@Injectable()` marks a class as available to Angular's DI system so that it can be injected into constructors. It allows you to define providers at module or component level.

patterns: How to provide a service globally
responses: To provide a service application-wide, add it to the root module `providers` array or use `providedIn: 'root'` in the `@Injectable()` decorator (recommended).

DI is a pattern where the framework injects required service instances into components. Angular's injector manages a container of service instances, creating them on demand and reusing singletons as configured.

patterns: How to make HTTP requests in Angular
responses: Import `HttpClientModule` from `@angular/common/http` in your NgModule imports. Use `HttpClient` injected into services to perform `get`, `post`, `put`, `delete` requests returning Observables.

patterns: How to use HttpClient in a service

responses: Observables (from RxJS) represent streams of async data. Unlike Promises, Observables can emit multiple values over time and support operators (map, filter, catch) for composition.

patterns: How to subscribe to an Observable
responses: Call `.subscribe()` on the Observable: `this.api.getItems().subscribe(data => this.items = data, err => console.error(err));`. Remember to manage subscriptions to avoid memory leaks (unsubscribe or use async pipe).
The `async` pipe in templates subscribes to an Observable or Promise and returns the latest value, automatically unsubscribing when the component is destroyed. Example: `{{ items$ | async }}`.
Angular Router maps URLs to components, enabling navigation between views without page reload. Configure routes with `Routes` and `RouterModule.forRoot(routes)`.

Define routes: `const routes: Routes = [{ path: 'about', component: AboutComponent }, { path: '', redirectTo: '/about', pathMatch: 'full' }];` then import `RouterModule.forRoot(routes)` in the module.

patterns: How to link routes in template
responses: Use `[routerLink]="['/about']"` or `routerLink="/about"` on anchors or buttons to navigate declaratively. Example: `<button routerLink="/contacts">Contacts</button>`.
`<router-outlet></router-outlet>` is a placeholder in a template where routed components are rendered by the Router based on the current URL.
Use `ActivatedRoute` to read route parameters: `this.id = +this.route.snapshot.params['id'];` or subscribe to `this.route.params` for dynamic changes.
Lazy loading splits app modules and loads them when the route is visited using `loadChildren`. Configure separate feature modules and reference them in the routes to reduce initial bundle size.

patterns: How to create forms with ngModel
responses: Template-driven forms use `ngModel` in templates and `FormsModule`. They're simpler for small forms. Reactive forms use `FormGroup`, `FormControl`, and `FormBuilder` from `@angular/forms` and are more scalable and testable.

Reactive forms use `FormGroup` and `FormControl`. Example:
```ts
this.form = this.fb.group({ name: ['', Validators.required] });
``` where `fb` is `FormBuilder` injected into the component.

Use validators like `Validators.required`, `Validators.minLength`. Check `form.controls.name.invalid` and `form.controls.name.touched` in the template to show errors. For template-driven, use `ngModel` and template variables like `#name="ngModel"`.
Built-in pipes include `date`, `uppercase`, `lowercase`, `currency`, `number`, `percent`, `json`. Use them as `{{ value | date:'shortDate' }}`.

patterns: How to create a custom pipe
responses: Create a pipe with `@Pipe({name:'myPipe'})` and implement `PipeTransform` with a `transform(value: any, ...args: any[])` method. Declare the pipe in a module's `declarations`.
Angular animations are provided by `@angular/animations`. Use `trigger`, `state`, `transition`, and `animate` in component metadata and import `BrowserAnimationsModule` in the app module.

patterns: Unit tests with Jasmine and Karma
responses: Angular uses Jasmine and Karma by default. Tests go in `.spec.ts` files. Run `ng test` to execute unit tests with Karma and view results in the browser.
Use `ng build --prod` (or `ng build --configuration production`) to create an optimized production build (minification, Ahead-of-Time compilation depending on Angular CLI version).

After `ng build`, deploy the `dist/your-app-name` folder to any static hosting or web server. Configure server to always serve `index.html` for client-side routes (fallback) to let the Angular router handle URLs.

patterns: How to add Bootstrap to Angular
Include CSS in angular.json or angular-cli.json
responses: Install Bootstrap: `npm install --save bootstrap@3` (or v4/5). Add the path to bootstrap.css in `angular.json` (or `.angular-cli.json` for older CLI) under `styles` so Angular includes it in the build.
Parent to child: use `@Input()` properties. Child to parent: use `@Output()` with an `EventEmitter`. Example: `<child [data]="parentData" (changed)="onChanged($event)"></child>`.
Common lifecycle hooks: `ngOnInit` (initialization), `ngOnChanges` (input changes), `ngDoCheck`, `ngAfterViewInit`, `ngOnDestroy` (cleanup). Use `ngOnInit` to perform component initialization logic.
Feature modules help modularize the app and enable lazy loading. A dedicated routing module (e.g. `AppRoutingModule`) centralizes routes and keeps AppModule cleaner.

patterns: Show error message on HTTP failure
responses: Use RxJS `catchError` and `pipe` to catch and handle errors in services. Example: `this.http.get(url).pipe(catchError(err => { console.error(err); return throwError(err); }));`
Use `new HttpHeaders({'Authorization': 'my-token'})` and pass it to `http.get(url, { headers })` or `http.post(url, body, { headers })` to send custom headers.

After login, store the JWT token (e.g. in `localStorage`) and add it to Authorization headers for subsequent requests. Use an `AuthService` to manage login/logout and an `HttpInterceptor` to attach the token automatically.

An `HttpInterceptor` intercepts HTTP requests/responses. Create a class implementing `HttpInterceptor`, add logic to clone the request and add headers, then provide it in the module using `HTTP_INTERCEPTORS` multi provider.

patterns: How the image search app works
responses: The Pixabay app queries `https://pixabay.com/api/?key=API_KEY&q=keyword&per_page=5&page=1`. The component calls a service or `Http` to fetch JSON, then renders `images.hits` with `*ngFor`. Pagination is handled by changing `page` and re-fetching.

The Contacts app has a Spring Boot backend exposing REST endpoints and an Angular frontend. The Angular app uses services to call `/contacts`, displays a list, shows detail, creates new contacts, and deletes contacts using HTTP methods.

Example (old Http):
```ts
getAllContacts(){ return this.http.get('http://localhost:8080/contacts').map(resp => resp.json()); }
``` For modern HttpClient replace `.map(resp => resp.json())` with typed `this.http.get<Contact[]>('/contacts')`.

The component reads `id` from `ActivatedRoute`, calls a service to fetch the contact by id, and displays fields such as name, email and photo. Navigation uses `this.router.navigate(['/detailContact', id])`.

patterns: How to show image detail on click
responses: Use a click handler `(click)="detailImage(im)"` to set `currentImage = im` and switch a `mode` flag to `'DETAIL'` so the template shows the detail view.
RxJS `map` transforms observable emissions. In modern RxJS use `pipe(map(...))`. With HttpClient you typically pipe and map the response to the needed shape.
AngularJS (1.x) uses MVC and plain JavaScript. Angular (2+) is a full rewrite using TypeScript, components, and a modular architecture with DI and improved performance.
Use `ng update` and the Angular Update Guide for version-specific instructions. Update dependencies in `package.json` and run `npm install`. Some breaking changes may require code updates.

patterns: ng generate ng build ng serve
responses: Common CLI commands: `ng new`, `ng serve`, `ng build`, `ng test`, `ng generate component|service|module`, `ng lint`, `ng add`.
Use `ng generate component component-name` or `ng g c name`. It creates component files and declares the component in the closest module.
Use `ng generate service service-name` or `ng g s name`. It scaffolds a service class and a `.spec.ts` test file.
Use `HttpClientModule` from `@angular/common/http`. The old `@angular/http` is deprecated. HttpClient returns typed Observables and has better features like interceptors.

patterns: Add Authorization header to http request
responses: Use `this.http.get(url, { headers: new HttpHeaders({ 'Authorization': token }) })` or implement an `HttpInterceptor` to attach the token automatically to each request.
Common operators: `map`, `filter`, `switchMap`, `mergeMap`, `concatMap`, `take`, `debounceTime`, `catchError`. Use `observable.pipe(map(...), catchError(...))` to compose.
Unsubscribe from subscriptions in `ngOnDestroy` or use the `async` pipe or operators like `takeUntil`/`take(1)` to auto-complete. For long-lived observables, always manage subscriptions.
Request a page parameter from server (`page`, `per_page`) and compute total pages from `totalHits` / `pageSize`. Build a `pages` array and call the API with the selected `page` index.

patterns: How to open preview on click
responses: Use `` and in the handler set the `currentImage` to the clicked object, then switch the view to show `currentImage.webformatURL` or `userImageURL` as needed.
Angular automatically sanitizes data bound into the DOM. Avoid using `innerHTML` with unsanitized content, or use `DomSanitizer` with caution. Protect backend APIs with proper auth and validation.

patterns: How to upload files in form
responses: Use `<input type="file" (change)="onFileSelected($event)">` and send the file using `FormData` in an HTTP POST: `formData.append('file', file)` then `this.http.post(url, formData)`.
Use `localStorage.setItem('token', jwt)` and `localStorage.getItem('token')`. For complex cases consider a service to abstract storage and secure sensitive info appropriately.
Use `ng lint` (CLI configuration). Newer projects use ESLint with Angular schematics. Linting enforces code style and catches potential issues early.
Use CI/CD tools (GitHub Actions, GitLab CI, Jenkins) to run `npm install`, `ng build --prod`, run tests, then deploy the `dist` folder to hosting (Netlify, Firebase Hosting, Apache, Nginx).

AOT (Ahead-of-Time) compiles templates into JS at build time, reducing runtime compilation overhead and improving startup speed. JIT compiles in the browser during runtime (development). Production builds often use AOT.
Source maps map compiled JS back to TypeScript sources so you can debug original code in the browser. CLI includes source maps by default in development builds.
Run `ng serve --port 4300` to change the dev server port. You can also configure the port in `angular.json` serve options.
CORS is a server-side policy. Enable CORS on the backend (add Access-Control-Allow-Origin header) or use a proxy during development (`proxy.conf.json`) to forward requests to the backend.

patterns: How to configure proxy for API requests
responses: Create `proxy.conf.json` with `{ "/api": { "target": "http://localhost:8080", "secure": false } }` and run `ng serve --proxy-config proxy.conf.json` so requests to `/api` are proxied to the backend.

patterns: How to fix module not found
responses: Check file paths and module imports. Ensure the module file exists and you exported/imported the module class correctly. Re-run `ng serve` after fixes.

patterns: component is not part of any NgModule
responses: Add the component class to the `declarations` array in the module where it should be used (usually AppModule or a feature module).

patterns: Can't bind to 'ngModel' since it isn't a known property
responses: Import `FormsModule` from `@angular/forms` and add it to the module `imports` where the component using `ngModel` is declared.

patterns: How to fix No provider for
responses: Provide the service either in `providers` of a module, use `@Injectable({ providedIn: 'root' })`, or add it to component `providers` if instance-per-component is required.
Ensure you imported the correct symbol at the top of the file (e.g. `import { HttpClient } from '@angular/common/http';`). Also install typings if needed and check `tsconfig.json`.
Read the error stack in the terminal; it usually contains file and line numbers. Fix TypeScript or import errors. Sometimes deleting `node_modules` and re-running `npm install` helps.
RxJS API changed between major versions. If operators like `map` are missing, ensure you're using `import { map } from 'rxjs/operators'` and using `.pipe(map(...))` instead of chaining map directly.
Check Angular Update Guide for upgrade steps and breaking changes. Update CLI, types, and fix deprecated APIs indicated by compiler errors or warnings.
Use a formatter like Prettier or ESLint with formatting rules. Configure editor settings to auto-format on save for consistent code style.
Use lazy loading for feature modules, AOT compilation, tree-shaking, minimize third-party libraries, and use `OnPush` change detection strategy for performance-critical components.

Angular's change detection checks component state and updates the DOM. Default strategy checks all bindings; `OnPush` runs checks only when input references change, improving performance when used correctly.
Angular supports i18n by extracting strings and building localized versions. Many teams use libraries like ngx-translate for runtime translation and more flexible workflows.

patterns: Should I add dist to gitignore
responses: Usually you should add `dist/` to `.gitignore` and generate it during CI/CD. Only commit built assets to specific branches if required by your hosting strategy.

patterns: How to do server side rendering
responses: Use Angular Universal for server-side rendering (SSR) which pre-renders pages on the server for better SEO and faster perceived load times.
Ionic is a mobile UI toolkit that integrates with Angular to build hybrid mobile apps using web technologies and Angular components.
`angular.json` holds build and serve configurations, asset and style entries, and environment configurations. Update it to include global styles, scripts, and build options.
Use `environment.ts` for dev settings and `environment.prod.ts` for production. The CLI replaces files during production builds. Import `environment` to read variables like API endpoints.
Place static images and files in the `src/assets` folder. Reference them in templates as `/assets/my-image.png` or via Angular asset configuration.

patterns: Unexpected token or syntax error in template
responses: Template parse errors often mean invalid HTML syntax or incorrect binding expressions. Check for missing brackets, wrong property names, or invalid structural directive placements.

patterns: What is difference between hot and cold
responses: Cold Observables start producing values for each subscriber. Hot Observables produce regardless of subscriptions (e.g., a shared subject). Use `share()` or `shareReplay()` to multicast values.
The `forRoot()` pattern provides providers needed once for the app (usually singleton services). Feature modules import a module without `forRoot()` to avoid duplicating providers.
`ng add` installs and configures libraries via schematics. For example `ng add @angular/material` installs Material and updates project files automatically.

patterns: How to protect backend from Angular
responses: Always validate and sanitize input on the backend, authenticate requests, implement authorization checks and rate limiting. Client-side checks are helpful UX but not a substitute for server-side validation.

patterns: How to send a POST request
responses: Use `this.http.post(this.host + '/tasks', task)` with `HttpClient`. It returns an Observable; subscribe to handle response or errors. Provide headers if needed.

patterns: How to send images to backend
responses: Use `FormData` to append file and other fields: `formData.append('photo', file)` and send via `http.post('/upload', formData)`; backend should accept multipart/form-data.
Call DELETE on the backend: `this.contactService.deleteContact(id).subscribe(() => this.ngOnInit());` to refresh the list after removal.
`switchMap` maps to a new Observable and cancels previous ones—useful for search inputs where only the latest request matters. `mergeMap` keeps all subscriptions.
